photo.title: Looking Down on Market Street From Ferry Building | October 18, 1906 | U00997

description._content: Within weeks of the #1906earthquake, San Francisco started piecing its transit system back together. By getting public transit moving and modernized, people were reconnected with their jobs and the outside world and rebuilding the city's houses and businesses was possible. Check out the full gallery of our reconstruction photos here: goo.gl/rZ7qyB

description._content:
Market Street
SF
architect of remodeling of old "Call" Building: Albert Roller

IM000125.JPG

photo.tags: sanfrancisco california monument marketstreet 3rdstreet kearnystreet refurbished gearystreet lottasfountain centraltower callbuilding albertroller

description._content:
Spreckels / San Francisco call Building
Third and market Streets
Built 1895 or so
Reid & Reid, architects
The building eventually stood 315 feet (96 m) tall with an ornate baroque dome-which housed the offices of Reid & Reid, the building's architects-and four corner cupolas when construction finished in 1898. It was the tallest building west of the Mississippi River for many years. The structure was badly burned and damaged by the 1906 San Francisco Earthquake, although the building did not collapse.

It is still standing-   In 1938 Albert Roller completely refurbished the renamed Central Tower. The building's height was reduced to 298 feet (91 m) and the number of stories was increased from 15 to 21; the ornate dome and the cupolas atop the building were removed.  

I'm curious how you can add floors and reduce height while using the same superstructure.........

San Francisco of yesteryear

2014-May-W 018

photo.title: The Call Building aka Central Tower - 701 Market Street, San Francisco

description._content: view from the west This tower once looked quite ornate, with dome and cupolas, before being stripped down to its present streamlined appearance in the 1930s. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Tower_%28San_Francisco%29 Here's a good summary by James R. Smith, author of "San Francisco’s Lost Landmarks": "... the Call Building still stands, now called Central Tower, a name as nondescript as the building. After purchasing the Call Building, Albert Roller learned that the structure could easily support six full stories above the fifteenth floor. He demolished the “uneconomical” baroque dome in 1937, replacing it with a new structure in the moderne style we now call Art Deco, modifying the entrance, lobby, and elevators with the classic art deco adornments and initiating our building into the modern age of Metropolis. The current structure is a treasure to aficionados of that style, but the city lost sight of one of its most recognizable landmarks." see: www.sfcityguides.org/public_guidelines.html?article=941&a... and Theaters

Smith, author of "San Francisco’s Lost Landmarks": "... the Call Building still stands, now called Central Tower, a name as nondescript as the building. After purchasing the Call Building, Albert Roller learned that the structure could easily support six full stories above the fifteenth floor. He demolished the “uneconomical” baroque dome in 1937, replacing it with a new structure in the moderne style we now call Art Deco, modifying the entrance, lobby, and elevators with the classic art deco adornments and initiating our building into the modern age of Metropolis.
